title: Against Bravery Debates
summary:
Key ideas:
- "Bravery debates" occur when people argue over who is being brave for holding a nonconformist position and who is cowardly for defending the status quo.
- The persistence of bravery debates is weird because these debates quickly make conversations horrible and infuriating.
- People tend to believe the deck is stacked against them, even when exposed to genuinely neutral information.
- Bravery debates are common and persistent because it is easy to get oneself perceived as the brave long-suffering underdog, which can lead to support and romantic desire.

Key learnings:
- Bravery debates are toxic and make conversations horrible and infuriating.
- Neutral information does not exist because people tend to believe the deck is stacked against them.
- Bravery debates persist because they work; people tend to support the brave long-suffering underdog who is perceived as the underdog.

Key questions:
- Should people get credit for being brave for holding a dangerous and unpopular position?
- Can opposing groups both be certain they are under siege? 
- How can we avoid falling into the trap of bravery debates?
